The **aqueous humour** is a transparent, watery [1] fluid similar to plasma,
but containing low protein concentrations. It is secreted from the [ciliary
epithelium](/wiki/Ciliary_body "Ciliary body"), a structure supporting the
lens.[2] It fills both the [anterior](/wiki/Anterior_chamber "Anterior
chamber") and the [posterior](/wiki/Posterior_chamber "Posterior chamber")
chambers of the eye, and is not to be confused with the [vitreous
humour](/wiki/Vitreous_humour "Vitreous humour"), which is located in the
space between the [lens](/wiki/Lens_\(anatomy\) "Lens \(anatomy\)") and the
retina, also known as the posterior cavity or vitreous chamber. [3]

## Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aqueous_humour&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Structure")]

### Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aqueous_humour&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Composition")]

  * [Amino acids](/wiki/Amino_acids "Amino acids"): transported by ciliary muscles
  * 98% water
  * [Electrolytes](/wiki/Electrolyte "Electrolyte")

Sodium = 142.09 Potassium = 2.2 - 4.0 Calcium = 1.8 Magnesium = 1.1 Chloride =
131.6 HCO3- = 20.15 Phosphate = 0.62 pH = 7.4 Osm = 304

  * [Ascorbic acid](/wiki/Ascorbic_acid "Ascorbic acid")
  * [Glutathione](/wiki/Glutathione "Glutathione")
  * [Immunoglobulins](/wiki/Immunoglobulins "Immunoglobulins")

## Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aqueous_humour&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Function")]

  * Maintains the [intraocular pressure](/wiki/Intraocular_pressure "Intraocular pressure") and inflates the globe of the eye. It is this hydrostatic pressure which keeps the eyeball in a roughly spherical shape and keeps the walls of the eyeball taut.
  * Provides nutrition (e.g. amino acids and glucose) for the avascular ocular tissues; posterior [cornea](/wiki/Cornea "Cornea"), [trabecular meshwork](/wiki/Trabecular_meshwork "Trabecular meshwork"), [lens](/wiki/Lens_\(anatomy\) "Lens \(anatomy\)"), and anterior vitreous.
  * May serve to transport [ascorbate](/wiki/Ascorbate "Ascorbate") in the anterior segment to act as an antioxidant agent.
  * Presence of [immunoglobulins](/wiki/Immunoglobulins "Immunoglobulins") indicate a role in immune response to defend against pathogens.
  * Provides inflation for expansion of the cornea and thus increased protection against dust, wind, pollen grains and some pathogens.
  * for [refractive index](/wiki/Refractive_index "Refractive index").

### Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aqueous_humour&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Production")]

Aqueous humour is secreted into the posterior chamber by the [ciliary
body](/wiki/Ciliary_body "Ciliary body"), specifically the non-pigmented
epithelium of the ciliary body ([pars plicata](/wiki/Pars_plicata "Pars
plicata")). 5 alpha-dihydrocortisol, an enzyme inhibited by [5-alpha reductase
inhibitors](/wiki/5-alpha_reductase_inhibitors "5-alpha reductase
inhibitors"), may be involved in production of aqueous humour.[4]

### Drainage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aqueous_humour&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Drainage")]

Aqueous humour is continually produced by the ciliary processes and this rate
of production must be balanced by an equal rate of aqueous humour drainage.
Small variations in the production or outflow of aqueous humour will have a
large influence on the intraocular pressure.

The drainage route for aqueous humour flow is first through the [posterior
chamber](/wiki/Posterior_chamber "Posterior chamber"), then the narrow space
between the posterior iris and the anterior lens (contributes to small
resistance), through the pupil to enter the [anterior
chamber](/wiki/Anterior_chamber "Anterior chamber"). From there, the aqueous
humour exits the eye through the [trabecular
meshwork](/wiki/Trabecular_meshwork "Trabecular meshwork") into [Schlemm's
canal](/wiki/Schlemm%27s_canal "Schlemm's canal") (a channel at the limbus,
i.e., the joining point of the cornea and sclera, which encircles the
cornea[5]) It flows through 25–30 collector canals into the episcleral veins.
The greatest resistance to aqueous flow is provided by the trabecular meshwork
(esp. the juxtacanalicular part), and this is where most of the aqueous
outflow occurs. The internal wall of the canal is very delicate and allows the
fluid to filter due to high pressure of the fluid within the eye.[5] The
secondary route is the uveoscleral drainage, and is independent of the
intraocular pressure, the aqueous flows through here, but to a lesser extent
than through the trabecular meshwork (approx. 10% of the total drainage
whereas by trabecular meshwork 90% of the total drainage).

The fluid is normally 15 mmHg (0.6 inHg) above atmospheric pressure, so when a
syringe is injected the fluid flows easily. If the fluid is leaking, due to
collapse and wilting of cornea, the hardness of the normal eye is therefore
corroborated.[5]

## Clinical
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Aqueous_humour&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Clinical significance")]

Main article: [Glaucoma](/wiki/Glaucoma "Glaucoma")

[Glaucoma](/wiki/Glaucoma "Glaucoma") is a progressive optic neuropathy where
retinal ganglion cells and their axons die causing a corresponding visual
field defect. An important risk factor is increased [intraocular
pressure](/wiki/Intraocular_pressure "Intraocular pressure") (pressure within
the eye) either through increased production or decreased outflow of aqueous
humour.[6] Increased resistance to outflow of aqueous humour may occur due to
an abnormal trabecular mesh work or to obliteration of the meshwork due to
injury or disease of the iris. However, increased interocular pressure is
neither sufficient nor necessary for development of primary open angle
glaucoma, although it is a major risk factor. Uncontrolled glaucoma typically
leads to visual field loss and ultimately [blindness](/wiki/Blindness
"Blindness").
